In the [near-impossible](https://www.cyclingnews.com/features/can-the-tour-de-france-end-in-a-tie/) event of a tie after all of the Tour de France's tiebreakers and no single winner of the general classification is declared, this question will be **annulled**." background_info="The [Tour de France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Tour_de_France) is an annual men's multiple stage bicycle race held primarily in France. It is the most prestigious bicycle race in the world. Its [112th edition](https://www.letour.fr/en/overall-route) will start in Lille, France, on July 5, 2025. The race will end on the Champs-Élysées in Paris on July 27, 2025.

Tadej Pogačar, [possibly the most gifted cyclist of all time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tadej_Poga%C4%8Dar#Comparisons_with_Eddy_Merckx), is favored to win this year's Tour. He has previously won the race in 2020, 2021, and 2024. However, his main rival, Jonas Vingegaard, is [exceptionally strong](https://www.welovecycling.com/wide/2023/07/26/opinion-pogacar-vs-vingegaard-is-already-the-tours-greatest-ever-rivalry/), and the Tour is [notoriously dangerous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_racing_cyclists_and_pacemakers_with_a_cycling-related_death); upsets and disaster are frequent." unit_of_measure='' close_time=datetime.datetime(2025, 7, 27, 5, 0) actual_resolution_time=None scheduled_resolution_time=datetime.datetime(2025, 7, 28, 15, 11) published_time=datetime.datetime(2025, 5, 2, 19, 0) open_time=datetime.datetime(2025, 5, 5, 17, 0) date_accessed=datetime.datetime(2025, 5, 20, 5, 25, 47, 194343) already_forecasted=False tournament_slugs=['metaculus-cup'] includes_bots_in_aggregates=False cp_reveal_time=datetime.datetime(2025, 5, 7, 17, 0) api_json={} options=['Tadej Pogačar', 'Jonas Vingegaard', 'Remco Evenepoel', 'Primož Roglič', 'João Almeida', 'Juan Ayuso', 'Other']

### Research Summary
The research focuses on the concerns expressed by Jonas Vingegaard, a two-time Tour de France winner, regarding the final stage of the 2025 Tour de France, which is set to include a climb through Montmartre. Vingegaard argues that the narrow streets of Montmartre will create unnecessary stress for the riders, particularly given the larger peloton of 150 cyclists compared to the 50 riders in the Olympic Games. He emphasizes that the organizers should prioritize a challenging yet exciting final stage without complicating the route. Remco Evenepoel, another prominent cyclist, has echoed similar sentiments, suggesting that the final stage should ideally favor sprinters on the Champs-Élysées instead.

Additionally, the organizers of the Tour de France are expected to reveal more details about the final stage's route soon, which may address the concerns raised by Vingegaard and others. The research highlights the differing opinions among cyclists regarding the route and the potential implications for the race's outcome.

# RESEARCH
## Report 1 Research
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Vingegaard Expresses Concerns Over Montmartre Stage in 2025 Tour de France**
Jonas Vingegaard, the two-time Tour de France winner, is not enthusiastic about the idea of the peloton passing through Montmartre during the final stage of the 2025 Tour de France. According to Vingegaard, 'it's not a good idea' because the narrow streets of Montmartre will add stress to the riders, who will be fighting for position in a crowded peloton of 150 riders. This is in contrast to the Olympic Games, where there were only 50 riders in the peloton. Vingegaard believes that the Tour de France organizers should not 'complicate things' and instead focus on providing a challenging and exciting final stage. Despite his concerns, Vingegaard is confident in his preparation and believes that he will be 'better than ever' at the start of the Tour de France, and is 'almost sure' that he will be able to compete for the victory.
Original language: fr
Publish date: May 19, 2025 04:29 PM
Source:[RMC SPORT](https://rmcsport.bfmtv.com/cyclisme/tour-de-france/tour-de-france-2025-pourquoi-vingegaard-n-est-pas-du-tout-emballe-par-le-passage-du-peloton-a-montmartre_AV-202505190668.html)

**Vingegaard and Evenepoel Speak Out Against Montmartre Stage in 2025 Tour de France**
Jonas Vingegaard, the two-time Tour de France winner, expressed his disapproval of the final stage of the 2025 Tour de France, which will include a climb up the Butte Montmartre in Paris. 'I'm not a fan of the idea,' Vingegaard said, 'Montmartre was nice during the Olympics, but it was with only 50 riders left in the peloton. On the Tour de France, we'll have 150 riders fighting for position on a very narrow climb, which could add more stress than needed.' This is not the first time a rider has spoken out against the idea, as Remco Evenepoel also expressed his disapproval in April, saying 'I don't think it's a good idea, it's unnecessary stress. The final stage is also a great opportunity for sprinters to shine on the Champs-Élysées, and it would likely result in a different finish.' 
Original language: fr
Publish date: May 19, 2025 04:21 PM
Source:[Le Parisien](https://www.leparisien.fr/sports/cyclisme/tour-de-france/tour-de-france-2025-je-ne-pense-pas-que-ce-soit-une-bonne-idee-vingegaard-pas-fan-de-letape-de-montmartre-19-05-2025-II2GFU5U4VHQHIR6OLYWAEJ6JE.php)

**Jonas Vingegaard Expresses Concerns About Montmartre Stage of 2025 Tour de France**
Jonas Vingegaard, the double winner of the Tour de France, expressed mixed feelings about the idea of the final stage of the 2025 Tour de France passing through Montmartre. While he initially said he didn't know what to think, he later stated that he's not a fan of the idea. Vingegaard expressed concerns about the narrow road and the large number of cyclists, which could generate unnecessary stress. The organizers of the Tour de France are expected to reveal the details of the final stage's route on Wednesday, May 21, 2025, which may alleviate or reinforce the concerns of the cyclists.

Publish date: May 19, 2025 04:00 PM

**Sam Watson Wins Vierdaagse van Duinkerke 2025**
The Vierdaagse van Duinkerke 2025 cycling tour concluded with Sam Watson winning the overall general classification. The final stage, won by Watson, secured his position at the top of the general classification. Watson's teammate Pierre Gautherat won stage 3, while Axel Zingle, who initially held the leader's jersey, was forced to abandon the tour after a crash. Zingle had won the first stage and held the leader's jersey until stage 4. Watson said, 'I am thrilled to have won the overall classification.' The final stage was won by Groupama-FDJ, with Watson crossing the finish line first, ahead of Lewis Askey and Carlos Canal.

**4 Jours de Dunkerque 2025: Samuel Watson Takes Overall Win**
The final stage of the 4 Jours de Dunkerque 2025 ended in a sprint, with Jake Stewart (Israel-Premier Tech) taking the win, ahead of Alberto Dainese (Tudor Pro Cycling Team) and Thibaud Gruel (Groupama-FDJ). Bernard Hinault, a five-time Tour de France winner, participated in a reconnaissance ride for the 7th stage of the 2025 Tour de France, which will start in Saint-Malo. **Gravel, drama and emotions on Strade Bianche stage 9 of the 2025 Giro d'Italia - Gallery**
Wout van Aert (Visma-Lease a Bike) won stage 9 of the 2025 Giro d'Italia, a 29.5km gravel section that brought a double dose of Strade Bianche to the race. Van Aert described the finish as 'perhaps the most beautiful place to finish a bike race', with the stunning vistas of Tuscany and enthusiastic tifosi support. The stage saw drama on the general classification front, with Isaac del Toro (UAE Team Emirates-XRG) taking the lead and teammate Juan Ayuso gaining time on Primož Roglič (Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe), who fell victim to the gravel roads with a crash and puncture. Van Aert's win marked his 50th as a pro and completed the Grand Tour trilogy of stage wins, adding a Giro triumph to his nine from the Tour de France and three from the Vuelta a España.

**Watson Wins Thrilling Stage at 4 Días de Dunkerque**
The 2025 edition of the 4 Días de Dunkerque lived up to its name with a thrilling stage on Saturday, as Samuel Watson (INEOS Grenadiers) took the win in a photo finish. The British rider was the fastest in the final meters after a grueling 171.8km stage with a final climb through narrow and winding streets. Carlos Canal (Movistar Team) finished a close second, confirming his strong form. The day started with a breakaway of four riders, but the peloton, controlled by the favorites' teams, caught up with them with 30km to go. Several attacks followed, but Watson's powerful sprint in the final kilometer secured the win, with Canal and Lewis Askey close behind. The stage was also marked by the abandonment of leader Axel Zingle (Visma-Lease a Bike), who crashed and was forced to withdraw. Watson now takes the lead in the general classification.

**Felix Orn-Kristoff Wins Tour de Bretagne 2025, Noah Hobbs Takes Final Stage**
The 58th edition of the Tour de Bretagne 2025 came to a close with Norwegian rider Felix Orn-Kristoff taking the overall victory. He had been in the lead since his win in the 4th stage. The final stage, a 159 km ride from Lanbédia to Plancoët, was won by British rider Noah Hobbs in a sprint finish. Hobbs, who has been in top form this week, took his third win of the week, having previously won the 2nd, 6th, and 7th stages. Orn-Kristoff's victory was secured after he maintained his lead in the general classification since his win in the 4th stage, as he said, 'I am thrilled to have won the overall title, it was a great day.'

**Tour de Bretagne 2025: Final Stage to Decide the Winner**
The Tour de Bretagne 2025 will conclude on Thursday, May 1st, with the seventh and final stage starting in Landébia (159 km). The men's strong contenders will compete for the victory and the succession of Swedish rider Jakob Söderqvist on the traditional final circuit in Plancoët. The winner will be announced around 5 pm on Thursday, May 1st, on the challenging circuit of Plancoët. This stage is the second most difficult of the tour, after the one arriving in Landévant, and will feature a similar route to the sixth stage, which was neutralized in 2023 due to a massive crash.

**Michael Storer Wins Tour of the Alps 2025**
Michael Storer won the Tour of the Alps 2025. Felix Gall, who finished second, said, 'It was not my all-time best day. In total, it were five very, very difficult days. I am satisfied and gave my best every day.' Gall praised Storer, saying, 'He was extremely strong throughout the entire tour.' The final stage of the tour had a festive atmosphere, with fans lining the streets and cheering on the riders. Gall's team, Decathlon-AG2R, had a strong performance, with Nicolas Prodhomme and Paul Seixas winning the final stage. Gall will now take a break before preparing for the Tour de France, which includes a high-altitude training session in the Sierra Nevada and the Tour the Swiss.

**Noah Hobbs Takes Lead in Tour de Bretagne 2025 After Stage 2 Victory**
Noah Hobbs (EF Education-Aevolo) won the second stage of the Tour de Bretagne 2025, a 182.2 km race between La Gouesnière and Le Cambout. The British sprinter took the overall lead in the general classification after Ilan Larmet (VC Rouen76) struggled. Hobbs, 20 years old, also won the stage, beating Ronan Augé (CIC - U - Nantes) and Antoine Hue (CIC - U - Nantes) in the sprint. Lewis Bower (Equipe continentale Groupama-FDJ) finished 9th, 9 seconds behind. As reported by Ouest France, Hobbs said, 'On est là pour apprendre' (We are here to learn) during an immersion with the VCP Loudéac team.

**Ilan Larmet Wins First Stage of 2025 Tour de Bretagne Cycliste**

content.text:
Here is the complete forecast and research summary for “Who will win the Tour de France 2025?” (Metaculus Q 36440).

—  
**Final Aggregated Prediction**  
- Tadej Pogačar: 33.6%  
- Jonas Vingegaard: 27.6%  
- Remco Evenepoel: 14.4%  
- Primož Roglič: 8.4%  
- João Almeida: 4.6%  
- Juan Ayuso: 4.0%  
- Other: 7.4%  

**Key Question Details**  
• Resolution criteria: Officially recognized winner of the general classification in the 2025 Tour de France, per the Tour website or other credible sources.  
• Fine print: If the winner is not named among the listed options, resolves as “Other.” In the event of a true tie after tiebreakers (extremely unlikely), the question is annulled.  
• Background: The 112th Tour runs July 5–27, 2025. Tadej Pogačar (3× champion) and Jonas Vingegaard (2×) are clear favorites, but mountains, crashes, and mechanicals often produce surprises.  
• Options: Tadej Pogačar; Jonas Vingegaard; Remco Evenepoel; Primož Roglič; João Almeida; Juan Ayuso; Other.  
• Official resolution date: by July 28, 2025 (15:11 UTC).

—  
**Research Highlights**  
1. Riders’ Top Concerns  
 – Jonas Vingegaard (2022 & 2023 winner) publicly criticized the inclusion of a Montmartre climb on Stage 21, warning that the narrow streets will create stress and increase crash risk in a full peloton of 150 (vs. 50 at the Olympics). Vingegaard and Remco Evenepoel both argued the final stage should favor sprinters on the Champs-Élysées instead. [RMC SPORT], [Le Parisien], [Ouest France]  
2. Course Implications  
 – The final‐stage route remains officially unpublished (to be revealed May 21), but Montmartre’s steep, narrow ascent could reshape GC battles or provoke crashes late on the last day.  
3. Form & History  
 – Pogačar: 2020, 2021, 2024 champion; widely regarded as the most gifted rider ever.  
 – Vingegaard: 2022, 2023 champion; strong climber and team support.  
 – Evenepoel: rising star with top‐5 in GC and strong time‐trial credentials.  
 – Roglič: experienced Grand Tour winner with podium pedigree.  
 – Almeida & Ayuso: emerging talents capable of seizing an upset if favorites falter.  
4. Upset Scenarios  
 – Crashes or illness derailing one or both favorites.  
 – Severe weather or mechanicals in key mountain stages.  
 – A dark‐horse rider avoids trouble and capitalizes on GC contenders’ misfortune.

—  
**Forecaster Reasoning (Summary)**  
• Nearly all forecasters (1–5) identify Pogačar as the top pick (30–35%) and Vingegaard as a strong second (25–30%).  
• Remco Evenepoel sits in the mid‐teens (12–15%).  
• Roglič is given 6–10%, with Almeida (3–5%) and Ayuso (3–5%) trailing.  
• “Other” scenarios (dark‐horse upset) range from 4–12%, reflecting Grand Tour volatility.

—  
**Sources**  
1. Vingegaard on Montmartre stage:  
 • RMC SPORT, May 19 2025: https://rmcsport.bfmtv.com/.../pling.../  
 • Le Parisien, May 19 2025: https://www.leparisien.fr/.../II2GFU5U4VHQHIR6OLYWAEJ6JE.php  
 • Ouest France, May 19 2025: https://www.ouest-france.fr/.../8ea76acc-...  
2. Tour de France 2025 overview:  
 • Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Tour_de_France  
 • Official route: https://www.letour.fr/en/overall-route  

Let me know if you’d like any additional details or a deeper dive into any rider’s prospects!

messages.content: How may I assist you today?

I am interested in forecasting and want to create a set of questions that will shed light on the state of judgemental forecasting and prediction markets in the next year. Could you help me come up with some good questions that could help us understand what the state of forecasting will look like in 3 months, and 1 year? Please come up with 5 questions for 3 months and 5 questions for 1 year.

I want to know about SWOT analysis items from all companies/websites/labs in the field. What new features will they create that we should be aware of? What black swans could come out of nowhere? What initiatives are people currently taking, would be worth it for other orgs to repeat? Don't just ask what their stats will be, but target the key things that will cause those stats. Throw in at least 1 conditional question.

content.text:
Okay, I can help you with that! Generating insightful questions is a great way to structure your thinking about the future of judgemental forecasting and prediction markets.

I will generate two sets of 5 questions each: one for the 3-month horizon and one for the 1-year horizon. These questions will aim to cover the aspects you mentioned, such as SWOT analysis, new features, black swan events, replicable initiatives, causal factors, and will include at least one conditional question.

Here are the questions I've generated for you:

general_research_and_approach='My approach starts with gathering general news on "judgemental forecasting and prediction markets". This provides a broad overview of current trends, key players, and recent developments. I see several articles mentioning Polymarket and Kalshi, as well as general discussions about the accuracy and challenges of prediction markets, and regulatory concerns.

Next, I'll perform targeted searches to gather information relevant to the specific question categories requested: SWOT analysis, new features, potential black swans, noteworthy initiatives, and drivers of change.

For SWOT, I'll search "SWOT analysis of Polymarket" and "SWOT analysis of Kalshi".
For new features, I'll search for "New features or product launches from Polymarket in next 3 months" and "New features or product launches from Kalshi in next 3 months".
For black swan events, I'll search for "Potential black swan events for prediction markets in the next 3 months".
For noteworthy initiatives and drivers of change, I'll synthesize information from the general news and the targeted searches, looking for patterns and innovations.

After these initial searches, I will synthesize the information and begin formulating potential questions. For each potential question, I will then perform a quick search to see if there's a way to find how that question might have resolved in the past, which is crucial for forecastability. This will involve queries like "How has [question] resolved in the past? Please provide a link to how to find this value or if you cannot find an exact resolution source, to suggest another question".

Based on these resolution searches, I will refine the questions to ensure they meet all criteria: high VOI, resolvable, specific, dated, and with a good resolution source. I anticipate needing to iterate on the question wording and focus. For example, a question about "user adoption" might be too vague, and I would refine it to be about a specific metric from a specific platform.

The news indicates Polymarket and Kalshi are major players. Regulatory issues are a recurring theme. The use of prediction markets for events like elections (Polymarket and the 2024 Trump victory prediction) and the expansion of Kalshi into sports betting are notable. The Bank of England's forecasting overhaul is interesting, but the query is about *other* organizations.

I'll aim to create questions across the requested categories, ensuring at least one is conditional. "New" action excludes ongoing compliance with the 2022 settlement. This question assesses the ongoing regulatory risk, a key threat/weakness.', past_resolution='Polymarket was ordered to pay a $1.4 million civil monetary penalty by the CFTC in January 2022 and to cease and desist from offering off-exchange event-based binary options contracts in the US. (Source: CFTC Press Release No. 8478-22, January 3, 2022, available at https://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/8478-22). Searching news archives for "Polymarket fine" or "Polymarket CFTC" can locate this. A quick search on "Polymarket regulatory action May 2024" or similar for very recent periods helps establish a baseline of no *new* major actions immediately prior to the forecast period.', other_information=None), DecomposedQuestion(question_or_idea_text='Kalshi to Launch Individual NFL Regular Season Game Outcome Contracts by August 20, 2025?', resolution_process="Check Kalshi's official website (markets page, blog, press releases) and major financial/betting news outlets for the listing of event contracts specifically on the outcomes (win/loss) of individual NFL regular season games for the 2025-2026 season.", expected_resolution_date='2025-08-20', background_information='Kalshi, a CFTC-regulated prediction market, has been expanding its sports-related offerings. They recently launched MLB game outcome contracts. Expansion into the NFL, a significantly larger market, would be a major product launch.', past_resolution='Kalshi announced the launch of markets for individual MLB game outcomes in April 2025. (Source: e.g., Covers.com article "Kalshi Launches MLB Game Markets Despite Scrutiny Over Sports Contracts," April 17, 2025. A search like "Kalshi MLB launch" would find such articles). This indicates a precedent for launching new sports categories.', other_information=None), DecomposedQuestion(question_or_idea_text='Unexpected Shutdown or Bankruptcy of a Top 3 Prediction Market by August 20, 2025?', resolution_process='Monitor official announcements (website, social media, press releases) from Polymarket, Kalshi, and PredictIt, and check major financial and cryptocurrency news outlets for any declarations of permanent shutdown of operations, insolvency, or bankruptcy filings by any of these three platforms.', expected_resolution_date='2025-08-20', background_information='"Top 3" refers to Polymarket, Kalshi, and PredictIt, which are frequently cited as leading platforms by user engagement or regulatory status. A sudden failure of one of these would be a high-impact "black swan" event for the sector.', past_resolution='While major cryptocurrency exchanges (like FTX in November 2022) have failed, directly comparable prediction markets of this scale have not typically shut down suddenly in very recent short windows. For example, searching "PredictIt shutdown 2024" or "Kalshi bankruptcy 2024" would return no such events, indicating their continued operation. The resolution involves checking for *new* announcements of failure.', other_information=None), DecomposedQuestion(question_or_idea_text='New G7 Central Bank (excluding BoE) or National Financial Regulator Announces Formal Integration of Prediction Market Data for Economic Forecasting by August 20, 2025?', resolution_process='Review official websites and press release sections of G7 central banks (Bank of Canada, European Central Bank, Bank of France, Deutsche Bundesbank, Bank of Italy, Bank of Japan, US Federal Reserve) and their respective national financial regulators (e.g., OSFI Canada, BaFin Germany, CONSOB Italy, FSA Japan, SEC/CFTC USA) for any public announcements of new formal initiatives, pilot programs, or frameworks explicitly stating the integration of data from prediction markets or an internal judgemental forecasting tournament for their official economic forecasting or policy guidance.', expected_resolution_date='2025-08-20', background_information='The Bank of England recently reviewed its forecasting methods. Monitor Kalshi's publicly available information (e.g., sections of their website detailing trading volumes if available, official press releases, or reputable financial news articles that explicitly cite average weekly trading volumes for Kalshi's MLB individual regular-season game outcome contracts) to determine if the average weekly trading volume for these specific MLB contracts exceeds $500,000 for any four consecutive weeks between May 20, 2025, and July 20, 2025. It posits that if a new product category (MLB game contracts) demonstrates significant user adoption (measured by a substantial trading volume of $500,000 average weekly for a month), Kalshi might be incentivized to further expand into other major sports leagues like the NFL or NBA. This tests if early market success directly drives broader product rollouts.', past_resolution='Specific conditional questions like this rarely have direct past resolutions in public records. However, Kalshi's general expansion strategy has involved launching new market categories over time. For example, its entry into MLB game markets in April 2025 followed earlier offerings of broader financial and political event contracts, and then sports futures. While specific volume thresholds for past expansions are not typically publicized, significant market activity is a known driver for business expansion. (News source for MLB launch: Covers.com, "Kalshi Launches MLB Game Markets Despite Scrutiny Over Sports Contracts," April 17, 2025. Search for "Kalshi trading volume" might reveal past high-level volume data, e.g., Sacra.com reported Kalshi averaged $42 million daily during the Nov 2024 election, indicating volume data is sometimes available for major events).', other_information=None)]

content.text:
### Questions for the 3-Month Horizon (by August 20, 2025)

1.  **New US Regulatory Action Against Polymarket by August 20, 2025?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** Review official announcements from US federal (e.g., CFTC, SEC, DOJ) and New York state regulatory agencies (e.g., NYDFS, NY Attorney General) and major financial news outlets for any new formal regulatory actions (e.g., fines, sanctions, lawsuits initiated, cease and desist orders) publicly announced against Polymarket or its key executives.
    *   **Background Information:** Polymarket, a leading prediction market, has faced past regulatory scrutiny in the US, notably settling with the CFTC in 2022 and agreeing to block US users. "New" action excludes ongoing compliance with the 2022 settlement. This question assesses the ongoing regulatory risk, a key threat/weakness.
    *   **Past Resolution:** Polymarket was ordered to pay a $1.4 million civil monetary penalty by the CFTC in January 2022 and to cease and desist from offering off-exchange event-based binary options contracts in the US. (Source: CFTC Press Release No. 8478-22, January 3, 2022, available at [https://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/8478-22](https://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/8478-22)).

2.  **Kalshi to Launch Individual NFL Regular Season Game Outcome Contracts by August 20, 2025?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** Check Kalshi's official website (markets page, blog, press releases) and major financial/betting news outlets for the listing of event contracts specifically on the outcomes (win/loss) of individual NFL regular season games for the 2025-2026 season.
    *   **Background Information:** Kalshi, a CFTC-regulated prediction market, has been expanding its sports-related offerings. They recently launched MLB game outcome contracts. Expansion into the NFL, a significantly larger market, would be a major product launch.
    *   **Past Resolution:** Kalshi announced the launch of markets for individual MLB game outcomes in April 2025. (Source: e.g., Covers.com article "Kalshi Launches MLB Game Markets Despite Scrutiny Over Sports Contracts," April 17, 2025.)

3.  **Unexpected Shutdown or Bankruptcy of a Top 3 Prediction Market by August 20, 2025?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** Monitor official announcements (website, social media, press releases) from Polymarket, Kalshi, and PredictIt, and check major financial and cryptocurrency news outlets for any declarations of permanent shutdown of operations, insolvency, or bankruptcy filings by any of these three platforms.
    *   **Background Information:** "Top 3" refers to Polymarket, Kalshi, and PredictIt, which are frequently cited as leading platforms by user engagement or regulatory status. A sudden failure of one of these would be a high-impact "black swan" event for the sector.
    *   **Past Resolution:** While major cryptocurrency exchanges (like FTX in November 2022) have failed, directly comparable prediction markets of this scale have not typically shut down suddenly in very recent short windows.

4.  **New G7 Central Bank (excluding BoE) or National Financial Regulator Announces Formal Integration of Prediction Market Data for Economic Forecasting by August 20, 2025?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** Review official websites and press release sections of G7 central banks (Bank of Canada, European Central Bank, Bank of France, Deutsche Bundesbank, Bank of Italy, Bank of Japan, US Federal Reserve) and their respective national financial regulators for any public announcements of new formal initiatives, pilot programs, or frameworks explicitly stating the integration of data from prediction markets or an internal judgemental forecasting tournament for their official economic forecasting or policy guidance.
    *   **Background Information:** The Bank of England recently reviewed its forecasting methods. This question explores if other major economic bodies will adopt similar innovative approaches. "Formal initiative" means a documented program or policy shift, not just a research paper.
    *   **Past Resolution:** Searches for such formal integrations by G7 central banks (excluding BoE) in the recent past (e.g., past 1-2 years) do not yield announcements of such formal integrations into official processes.

5.  **Conditional on High MLB Volume, Will Kalshi Announce Expansion to NFL/NBA Regular Season Game Contracts by August 20, 2025?**
    *   **Resolution Process:**
        1.  Monitor Kalshi's publicly available information to determine if the average weekly trading volume for its MLB individual regular-season game outcome contracts exceed $500,000 for any four consecutive weeks between May 20, 2025, and July 20, 2025. If such specific volume data is not made publicly available by July 20, 2025, the condition will be deemed not met.
        2.  If the condition in step 1 is met, then monitor Kalshi's official announcements and major financial/betting news outlets until August 20, 2025, for any public announcement of the intent to list, or the actual listing of, event contracts on individual regular-season game outcomes for either the NFL or NBA.
    *   **Background Information:** This conditional question aims to identify an underlying driver of strategic expansion. It posits that if a new product category (MLB game contracts) demonstrates significant user adoption, Kalshi might be incentivized to expand into other major sports leagues.
    *   **Past Resolution:** Specific conditional questions like this rarely have direct past resolutions. However, Kalshi's general expansion strategy has involved launching new market categories over time (e.g., MLB game markets in April 2025).

### Questions for the 1-Year Horizon (by May 20, 2026)

1.  **Will Polymarket announce any new partnerships with traditional financial institutions (e.g., banks, investment firms) or major regulated media outlets (e.g., established newspapers with national circulation, major television news networks) via its official blog or primary X (Twitter) feed by May 20, 2026?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** Review Polymarket's official blog and primary official X (Twitter) feed for any announcements of new partnerships fitting the criteria between May 21, 2025, and May 20, 2026.
    *   **Background Information:** Partnerships with established financial institutions or major regulated media could signify mainstream adoption or increased regulatory comfort for Polymarket.
    *   **Past Resolution:** Between May 20, 2024, and May 20, 2025, Polymarket announced a partnership with Perplexity (an AI search engine, not a traditional financial institution or regulated media outlet) in August 2024 (Source: TechCrunch, [https://techcrunch.com/2024/08/12/prediction-market-polymarket-partners-with-perplexity-to-show-news-summaries/](https://techcrunch.com/2024/08/12/prediction-market-polymarket-partners-with-perplexity-to-show-news-summaries/)).

2.  **By May 20, 2026, will Kalshi introduce and feature on its main platform at least two new *distinct event contract categories* that are not primarily sub-categories of its existing 12 categories listed as of May 20, 2025?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** On May 20, 2026, review the categories of event contracts listed on Kalshi's official website. Compare this to the 12 categories listed as of May 20, 2025 (Politics, Sports, Culture, Crypto, Climate, Economics, Companies, Financials, Tech & Science, Health, World, Transportation).
    *   **Background Information:** The introduction of new event categories reflects Kalshi's growth strategy and expansion into new forecasting areas.
    *   **Past Resolution:** As of May 20, 2025, Kalshi listed 12 distinct categories. The number of top-level categories appeared stable from May 2024 to May 2025.

3.  **Between May 21, 2025, and May 20, 2026, will either The Block Crypto or Cointelegraph publish an article confirming a security breach leading to a direct loss of user funds, or a regulatory shutdown ordering cessation of services, specifically for a prediction market platform that had a self-reported or independently estimated total annual trading volume exceeding $5 million USD in the 12 months prior to the event?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** On May 21, 2026, search the websites of The Block Crypto and Cointelegraph for articles published between May 21, 2025, and May 20, 2026, using relevant keywords.
    *   **Background Information:** This question gauges the operational and regulatory stability of larger prediction market platforms.
    *   **Past Resolution:** Based on a search for the period May 20, 2024, to May 20, 2025, no articles were found detailing such an event for a prediction market platform meeting the volume criteria.

4.  **By May 20, 2026, will the official websites of Good Judgment Inc. (goodjudgment.com) or Hypermind (hypermind.com) collectively feature at least one new publicly accessible case study or whitepaper that explicitly names a company from the S&P 100 list (as of January 1, 2025) as a client or details a project undertaken with them?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** On May 20, 2026, review the "Case Studies," "Resources," "Clients," or similar sections on goodjudgment.com and hypermind.com. Compare the list of case studies/whitepapers featuring named S&P 100 companies to those available on May 20, 2025.
    *   **Background Information:** Adoption by S&P 100 companies, showcased publicly, would indicate growing corporate trust in these judgemental forecasting services.
    *   **Past Resolution:** As of May 20, 2025, neither Good Judgment Inc. nor Hypermind explicitly listed case studies or whitepapers featuring named S&P 100 companies on their public websites. (Source: Good Judgment Case Studies page [https://goodjudgment.com/resources/case-studies/](https://goodjudgment.com/resources/case-studies/)).

5.  **If a prediction market platform's native utility token (not previously listed on Kraken) gets newly listed for trading on Kraken by November 20, 2025, will its average daily trading volume across all exchanges in the 30 days *following* the Kraken listing be at least 50% greater than its average daily trading volume in the 30 days *prior* to the Kraken listing announcement?**
    *   **Resolution Process:** Monitor announcements from Kraken and prediction market platforms for new listings. If such a listing occurs, use a reputable crypto data aggregator (e.g., CoinMarketCap, CoinGecko) to find the token's historical daily trading volume. Calculate the average daily volume for the 30 days immediately preceding the listing announcement and the 30 days starting from the listing date. Compare the two averages.
    *   **Background Information:** Listing on a major exchange like Kraken can significantly increase a token's visibility and trading volume. This question explores the "exchange listing effect" for prediction market tokens.
    *   **Past Resolution:** For a comparable example, Flux (FLUX) was listed on Binance on December 10, 2021. One would access historical data from CoinMarketCap (e.g., [https://coinmarketcap.com/currencies/zel/flux/historical-data/](https://coinmarketcap.com/currencies/zel/flux/historical-data/)) or CoinGecko for the relevant periods to calculate the percentage change in average daily volume.

I hope these questions are helpful for your forecasting efforts! Let me know if you have any other requests.

messages.output:
The European Union has significantly revised its economic growth forecasts downward for 2025 and 2026, citing heightened global trade tensions and uncertainty stemming from U.S. tariffs. Here's a detailed analysis:

## Growth Forecast Revisions
- **Eurozone**: Growth cut to **0.9% for 2025** (from 1.3%) and **1.4% for 2026** (from 1.6%)[1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast)[3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).  
- **EU-wide**: Reduced to **1.1% for 2025** (from 1.5%) and **1.5% for 2026** (from 1.8%)[3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910)[4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/)[7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html).  
- **Germany**, the bloc's largest economy, is now projected to see **zero growth in 2025** – a sharp downgrade from 0.7% previously[1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).

## Key Drivers of Uncertainty
**1. U.S. Tariff Impacts**  
- Trump administration imposed **25% tariffs on steel, aluminum, and auto imports**, with a "baseline" 10% duty on most EU goods[1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).  
- Potential escalation to **20% tariffs on EU goods** if negotiations fail by July 2025[1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast)[7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html).  
- These measures have created a "weakening global trade outlook" and disrupted supply chains[1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast)[3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).

**2. Trade Dynamics**  
- EU exports projected to grow only **0.7% in 2025**, with goods exports expected to contract[2](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/05/19/spring-2025-economic-forecast-how-much-will-trumps-tariffs-hinder-eu-growth)[4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/)[7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html).  
- Services exports remain resilient but insufficient to offset manufacturing declines[2](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/05/19/spring-2025-economic-forecast-how-much-will-trumps-tariffs-hinder-eu-growth)[5](https://commission.europa.eu/news/eu-economy-projected-moderately-grow-amid-global-economic-uncertainty-2025-05-19_en).  
- Global trade growth slowing to **2.1% in 2025**, down from pre-tariff projections[4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/)[7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html).

## Economic Implications
- **Inflation**: Expected to ease to **2.1% in eurozone (2025)** and **1.7% by 2026**, as trade tensions dampen demand[3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910)[4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/)[5](https://commission.europa.eu/news/eu-economy-projected-moderately-grow-amid-global-economic-uncertainty-2025-05-19_en).  
- **Labor Markets**: Remain robust with **2 million new EU jobs projected for 2026**, supporting domestic consumption[5](https://commission.europa.eu/news/eu-economy-projected-moderately-grow-amid-global-economic-uncertainty-2025-05-19_en)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).  
- **Competitiveness Shift**: EU pivoting from climate-focused policies to business competitiveness measures against U.S. and Chinese firms[1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).

## Risks and Outlook
- **Downside Risks**: Further trade fragmentation could reduce GDP by **0.5-1.0%** and rekindle inflation through supply shocks[4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/)[7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html)[8](http://en.people.cn/n3/2025/0520/c90000-20316809.html).  
- **Financial Stability**: Stress in non-bank institutions could spill into credit markets[4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/)[7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html).  
- **Negotiation Window**: Current tariff freeze until July 2025 creates urgency for EU-U.S. trade deal[1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).

The EU's economic trajectory now hinges on resolving trade disputes while maintaining domestic demand through wage growth and employment stability. However, the Commission warns that prolonged uncertainty could extend the growth slowdown into 2026[3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910)[4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/)[6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519).

content.text:
I found the following information regarding EU economic growth expectations and global trade uncertainty:

The European Union has significantly revised its economic growth forecasts downward for 2025 and 2026, citing heightened global trade tensions and uncertainty stemming from U.S. tariffs.

**Growth Forecast Revisions:**
*   **Eurozone:** Growth cut to **0.9% for 2025** (from 1.3%) and **1.4% for 2026** (from 1.6%). [1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast) [3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910) [6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519)
*   **EU-wide:** Reduced to **1.1% for 2025** (from 1.5%) and **1.5% for 2026** (from 1.8%). [3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910) [4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/) [7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html)
*   **Germany,** the bloc's largest economy, is now projected to see **zero growth in 2025** – a sharp downgrade from 0.7% previously. [1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast) [6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519)

**Key Drivers of Uncertainty:**
*   **U.S. Tariff Impacts:** The Trump administration imposed **25% tariffs on steel, aluminum, and auto imports,** with a "baseline" **10% duty on most EU goods.** There's potential escalation to **20% tariffs on EU goods** if negotiations fail by July 2025 [1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast). These measures have created a "weakening global trade outlook" and disrupted supply chains. [1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast) [3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910) [6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519)
*   **Trade Dynamics:** EU exports are projected to grow only **0.7% in 2025,** with goods exports expected to contract. [2](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/05/19/spring-2025-economic-forecast-how-much-will-trumps-tariffs-hinder-eu-growth) [4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/) [7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html) Services exports remain resilient but insufficient to offset manufacturing declines. [2](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/05/19/spring-2025-economic-forecast-how-much-will-trumps-tariffs-hinder-eu-growth) [5](https://commission.europa.eu/news/eu-economy-projected-moderately-grow-amid-global-economic-uncertainty-2025-05-19_en) Global trade growth is slowing to **2.1% in 2025,** down from pre-tariff projections. [4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/) [7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html)

**Economic Implications:**
*   **Inflation:** Expected to ease to **2.1% in the eurozone (2025)** and **1.7% by 2026,** as trade tensions dampen demand. [3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910) [4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/) [5](https://commission.europa.eu/news/eu-economy-projected-moderately-grow-amid-global-economic-uncertainty-2025-05-19_en)
*   **Labor Markets:** Remain robust with **2 million new EU jobs projected for 2026,** supporting domestic consumption. [5](https://commission.europa.eu/news/eu-economy-projected-moderately-grow-amid-global-economic-uncertainty-2025-05-19_en) [6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519)
*   **Competitiveness Shift:** The EU is pivoting from climate-focused policies to business competitiveness measures against U.S. and Chinese firms. [1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast) [6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519)

**Risks and Outlook:**
*   **Downside Risks:** Further trade fragmentation could reduce GDP by **0.5-1.0%** and rekindle inflation through supply shocks. [4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/) [7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html) [8](http://en.people.cn/n3/2025/0520/c90000-20316809.html)
*   **Financial Stability:** Stress in non-bank institutions could spill into credit markets. [4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/) [7](https://english.news.cn/europe/20250519/e8da4458effc499abb2adee5fed75ab3/c.html)
*   **Negotiation Window:** The current tariff freeze until July 2025 creates urgency for an EU-U.S. trade deal. [1](https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/general/3029235/trump-tariffs-force-eu-to-cut-2025-eurozone-growth-forecast) [6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519)

The EU's economic trajectory now hinges on resolving trade disputes while maintaining domestic demand through wage growth and employment stability. However, the Commission warns that prolonged uncertainty could extend the growth slowdown into 2026. [3](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/economy/eu-cuts-economic-growth-forecasts-amid-tariff-uncertainty/3572910) [4](https://www.shine.cn/news/world/2505198299/) [6](https://www.mitrade.com/insights/news/live-news/article-3-829219-20250519)

Here are the decomposed sub-questions:

1.  **Question:** Will the European Commission's Autumn 2025 Economic Forecast revise the EU's 2026 real GDP growth forecast downwards by at least 0.2 percentage points compared to the Spring 2025 forecast (1.4% for Eurozone, 1.5% for EU), explicitly citing "trade uncertainty," "tariffs," or "protectionism" as a primary reason?
    *   **Resolution Process:** Review the European Commission's Autumn 2025 Economic Forecast (typically released in November). Compare the 2026 real GDP growth forecast for the EU with the 1.4% (Eurozone) / 1.5% (EU) figure from the Spring 2025 Economic Forecast. Check the accompanying text for explicit mentions of "trade uncertainty," "tariffs," or "protectionism" as primary reasons for any downward revision of at least 0.2 percentage points.
    *   **Expected Resolution Date:** 2025-12-31
    *   **Background Information:** The European Commission's Spring 2025 Economic Forecast (published May 19, 2025) already lowered growth expectations for 2025 due to trade uncertainties, particularly US tariff policies. This question assesses if these concerns will further impact the 2026 outlook. A 0.2 percentage point revision is a significant change in such forecasts.
    *   **Past Resolution:** In the Spring 2025 Economic Forecast, the Commission revised the 2025 EU GDP growth forecast down to 1.1% from 1.5% projected in Autumn 2024 (a 0.4ppt revision for the EU), explicitly citing "the impact of increased tariffs and the heightened uncertainty caused by the recent abrupt changes in US trade policy." (Source: European Commission, Spring 2025 Economic Forecast, [https://economy-finance.ec.europa.eu/economic-forecast-and-surveys/economic-forecasts/spring-2025-economic-forecast-moderate-growth-amid-global-economic-uncertainty_en](https://economy-finance.ec.europa.eu/economic-forecast-and-surveys/economic-forecasts/spring-2025-economic-forecast-moderate-growth-amid-global-economic-uncertainty_en))

2.  **Question:** According to Eurostat's first estimate for the full year 2025, will the EU's trade in goods surplus with the United States be lower than the €157 billion recorded for 2023?
    *   **Resolution Process:** Obtain Eurostat's first estimate for the EU's international trade in goods with the US for the full year 2025 (exports minus imports). This data is typically released by Eurostat in February/March of the following year. Compare this figure to the €157 billion surplus recorded for 2023.
    *   **Expected Resolution Date:** 2026-03-31
    *   **Background Information:** The EU recorded a trade in goods surplus with the US of €157 billion in 2023. Increased US protectionism or a slowdown in US demand could reduce this surplus. This tracks a key direct impact of trade relations.
    *   **Past Resolution:** The EU's trade in goods surplus with the US was €205.6 billion in 2022 and fell to €157 billion in 2023. (Source: Eurostat [https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=USA-EU_-_international_trade_in_goods_statistics](https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php?title=USA-EU_-_international_trade_in_goods_statistics) for 2022 data, and European Commission [https://policy.trade.ec.europa.eu/eu-trade-relationships-country-and-region/countries-and-regions/united-states_en](https://policy.trade.ec.europa.eu/eu-trade-relationships-country-and-region/countries-and-regions/united-states_en) for 2023 data).

3.  **Question:** Between June 1, 2025, and December 31, 2025, will the EU initiate more than one new formal trade dispute consultation against the United States at the World Trade Organization (WTO) where US tariffs or trade-related measures are cited as the primary concern?
    *   **Resolution Process:** Monitor the WTO's official dispute settlement database ([https://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/dispu_status_e.htm](https://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/dispu_status_e.htm)) for new requests for consultation initiated by the EU against the US. Count the number of such unique dispute cases filed within the specified period where tariffs/trade measures are the focus.
    *   **Expected Resolution Date:** 2026-01-15
    *   **Background Information:** Increased trade friction often leads to formal disputes. The EU has countermeasures prepared against recent US tariffs, with a suspension until mid-July 2025. The number of new WTO cases is an indicator of escalating trade tensions and the EU's response.
    *   **Past Resolution:** In response to US steel and aluminum tariffs imposed in 2018, the EU filed one major WTO challenge (DS548) on June 1, 2018. (Source: WTO Dispute Settlement database, DS548: United States — Certain Measures on Steel and Aluminum Products).

4.  **Question:** Will the value of EU exports of "Motor cars and other motor vehicles principally designed for the transport of persons" (HS Code 8703) to the USA for the period July-December 2025 be at least 5% lower than the value reported for July-December 2024, according to Eurostat data?
    *   **Resolution Process:** Access Eurostat's international trade database (Comext) after the data for December 2025 becomes available (likely February/March 2026). Extract the value of EU exports to the USA for HS code 8703 for July-December 2025 and July-December 2024. Calculate the percentage change.
    *   **Expected Resolution Date:** 2026-03-31
    *   **Background Information:** The automotive sector is a significant component of EU-US trade and has been subject to tariff threats and actual tariff impositions (e.g. US has a general 25% tariff on cars as of May 2025). A decline in export value in this key sector would be a tangible impact of trade uncertainty and/or tariffs.
    *   **Past Resolution:** While a direct comparison for this specific period and product code post-2025 tariffs isn't available yet, historical data from Eurostat can show fluctuations. For instance, during previous trade tensions (e.g., 2018-2019), specific sectors experienced export declines due to tariffs or the threat thereof. For example, S&P Global noted in March 2025 that if the UK (a former EU member but indicative) cannot avoid newly announced 25% tariffs on car exports to the US, it could result in a 0.2% hit to its GDP ([https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/03/29/tariffs-and-defence-spending-sp-global-slashes-eurozone-and-uk-growth-forecast](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/03/29/tariffs-and-defence-spending-sp-global-slashes-eurozone-and-uk-growth-forecast)). Eurostat is the definitive source for past export values.

5.  **Question:** Will Eurostat's first flash estimate for Eurozone quarter-on-quarter real GDP growth for Q3 2025 be 0.1% or lower?
    *   **Resolution Process:** Check Eurostat's news release for the Q3 2025 flash estimate of quarterly GDP growth for the Eurozone (typically released end of October/early November of the same quarter or shortly after).
    *   **Expected Resolution Date:** 2025-11-15
    *   **Background Information:** The European Commission's Spring 2025 forecast projects modest Eurozone GDP growth of 0.9% for 2025. Continued or increased trade uncertainty through mid-2025 could lead to very low or stagnant growth in Q3. The Q1 2025 growth was 0.4%, better than expected, but uncertainty persists.
    *   **Past Resolution:** Eurostat's first flash estimate for Eurozone Q4 2024 GDP growth was 0.0% (stagnation), released on January 30, 2025 (later revised). (Source: Example based on pattern, for Q4 2024, the flash estimate was released on 30 Jan 2025, details here: [https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/19738797/2-30012025-AP-EN.pdf/](https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/19738797/2-30012025-AP-EN.pdf)). The actual Q1 2025 flash estimate was 0.4% QoQ.

**Step 4: Operationalize this question**

I'll pick the first sub-question to operationalize: "Will the European Commission's Autumn 2025 Economic Forecast revise the EU's 2026 real GDP growth forecast downwards by at least 0.2 percentage points compared to the Spring 2025 forecast (1.4% for Eurozone, 1.5% for EU), explicitly citing "trade uncertainty," "tariffs," or "protectionism" as a primary reason?"

content.text:
Here is the operationalized question:

*   **Question Text:** Will the European Commission's Autumn 2025 Economic Forecast revise the EU's 2026 real GDP growth forecast downwards by at least 0.2 percentage points compared to the Spring 2025 forecast, explicitly citing trade uncertainty as a contributing factor?
*   **Resolution Criteria:** This question resolves as Yes if the [Autumn 2025 Economic Forecast](https://economy-finance.ec.europa.eu/economic-forecast-and-surveys/economic-forecasts_en), published on the European Commission’s official website, meets both criteria:
    1.  The EU’s 2026 real GDP growth forecast is ≤1.3% (a ≥0.2 percentage point decrease from the Spring 2025 forecast of 1.5%).
    2.  The report explicitly cites trade uncertainty (e.g., tariffs, geopolitical tensions, or trade policy disruptions) as a reason for the revision.
*   **Fine Print:**
    *   If the Autumn 2025 forecast is delayed beyond December 31, 2025, the question will resolve using the first official forecast published by January 15, 2026.
    *   Revisions must apply to the EU aggregate (not individual countries or the Eurozone).
    *   If the numerical threshold is met but trade uncertainty is not cited, the question resolves as No. If trade uncertainty is one of multiple cited factors, it resolves as Yes.
    *   Forecasts from unofficial sources (e.g., leaks, drafts) will not be considered.
*   **Background Information:** The European Commission’s [Spring 2025 Economic Forecast](https://economy-finance.ec.europa.eu/economic-forecast-and-surveys/economic-forecasts/spring-2025-economic-forecast-moderate-growth-amid-global-economic-uncertainty_en) (published May 19, 2025) already reduced the EU’s 2025 growth outlook to 1.1% (from 1.5% in Autumn 2024), attributing this to “increased tariffs and heightened uncertainty from abrupt US trade policy changes.” The 2026 projection remained at 1.5%, contingent on stabilizing trade conditions. Recent US tariff hikes under the Trump administration and retaliatory EU measures have intensified trade risks, with analysts warning of potential spillover effects into 2026.
*   **Expected Resolution Date:** 2025-11-30
*   **Question Type:** binary

# SUMMARY
*Question*: Will the European Commission's Autumn 2025 Economic Forecast revise the EU's 2026 real GDP growth forecast downwards by at least 0.2 percentage points compared to the Spring 2025 forecast, explicitly citing trade uncertainty as a contributing factor?
*Final Prediction*: 60.0%
*Total Cost*: $1.5215
*Time Spent*: 0.52 minutes


## Report 1 Summary
### Forecasts
*Forecaster 1*: 60.0%
*Forecaster 2*: 60.0%
*Forecaster 3*: 65.0%
*Forecaster 4*: 60.0%
*Forecaster 5*: 70.0%


### Research Summary
The European Commission's Spring 2025 Economic Forecast has revised the growth projections for the EU and Eurozone downward, primarily due to increasing global trade tensions and uncertainties surrounding trade policies. The forecast now anticipates a growth rate of 1.1% for the EU in 2025 and 1.5% in 2026, down from previous estimates of 1.5% and 1.8%, respectively. For the Eurozone, the growth is expected to be 0.9% in 2025 and 1.4% in 2026, a decrease from earlier forecasts of 1.3% and 1.6%. The report highlights that the downward revisions are significantly influenced by a weakening global trade outlook and the high levels of uncertainty related to trade policy, particularly due to new tariffs imposed by the US.

European Commissioner for Economy Valdis Dombrovskis emphasized that the EU economy, while starting the year on a stronger footing than expected, is facing challenges from global uncertainties that are weighing on growth. The report also notes that inflation is projected to decrease, with rates expected to fall to 2.1% in 2025 and 1.7% in 2026 for the Eurozone. The overall economic environment remains fragile, with risks oriented downwards, and the Commission urges decisive actions to enhance the EU's competitiveness in light of these challenges.

Sources:
- [HABERTURK.COM](https://www.haberturk.com/ab-2025-yili-ekonomik-buyume-tahminini-dusurdu-3792233-ekonomi)
- [birgun.net](https://www.birgun.net/haber/ab-komisyonu-2025-buyume-tahminlerini-asagi-yonlu-revize-etti-624219)
- [ECO](https://eco.sapo.pt/2025/05/19/o-momento-da-europa-para-agir-e-agora/)
- [Il Messaggero](https://www.ilmessaggero.it/economia/news/dazi_ue_riduce_stime_pil_cosa_succede-8845536.html)
- [ANSA.it](https://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/economia/2025/05/19/lue-taglia-la-stima-sul-pil-dellitalia-07-nel-2025-09-nel-2026_d384818e-bb75-476c-ae45-3af09b0e9117.html)


# RESEARCH
## Report 1 Research
Here are the relevant news articles:

**EU Economic Growth Projections Revised Downward**
The European Commission's 'European Economic Projections 2025 Spring' report has been published. According to the report, despite global economic uncertainty, the EU economy has started the year on a stronger footing than expected, with moderate growth expected to continue this year, and a slight acceleration in growth expected in 2026, despite increasing global policy uncertainty and trade tensions. The report forecasts that the EU economy will grow by 1.1% in 2025 and 1.5% in 2026, while the Eurozone economy is expected to grow by 0.9% in 2025 and 1.4% in 2026. This is a downward revision of the Commission's previous 'autumn' report, which forecasted growth of 1.5% in 2025 and 1.8% in 2026 for the EU, and 1.3% in 2025 and 1.6% in 2026 for the Eurozone. The report states, 'The current forecast has been significantly revised downwards, mainly due to the weakening global trade outlook and high uncertainty related to trade policy.'
Original language: tr
Publish date: May 19, 2025 12:43 PM
Source:[HABERTURK.COM](https://www.haberturk.com/ab-2025-yili-ekonomik-buyume-tahminini-dusurdu-3792233-ekonomi)

**European Commission Revises 2025 and 2026 Growth Forecasts Downward**
The European Commission has revised its economic growth forecasts for 2025 and 2026 downward due to global trade tensions and increasing uncertainties. The growth forecast for the Eurozone has been revised from 1.3% to 0.9% for this year, while inflation is expected to continue its downward trend. The European Commission's '2025 Spring European Economic Forecasts' report states that the EU's economy is stronger than expected at the beginning of the year, but global trade tensions and uncertainties are slowing down growth. The report predicts that the EU's economy will grow by 1.1% in 2025 and 1.5% in 2026. For the Eurozone, the growth rate is expected to be 0.9% in 2025 and 1.4% in 2026. This is a significant decrease from the previous forecast of 1.3% and 1.6%. The revision is attributed to the slowdown in global trade flows and high levels of ongoing trade policy uncertainty. According to the report, Austria's economy is expected to shrink by 0.3% in 2025, while Germany's economy is expected to remain stagnant. France is expected to grow by 0.6%, Italy by 0.7%, and Spain by 2.6% in 2025, while in 2026, Germany is expected to grow by 1.1%, France by 1.3%, Italy by 0.9%, and Spain by 2%. Inflation is expected to be 2.3% in 2025 for the EU and 2.1% for the Eurozone, while in 2026, these rates are expected to decrease to 1.9% and 1.7%, respectively. The report also notes that the US's new tariffs have had a significant impact on global markets, and that the uncertainty surrounding trade policies has increased the pressure on the global economy, affecting the EU directly. The report concludes that the EU's exports will be slowed down by the global demand weakness, and that the trade tensions will continue to have a negative impact on the EU's economy. The report also warns that the commercial fragmentation can have negative effects on growth and that there is a risk of re-emerging inflationary pressures. The report also mentions Turkey's economy, stating that the country's economy is expected to grow by 2.8% in 2025 and 3.5% in 2026, due to the effects of tight monetary and fiscal policies, as well as the decline in energy prices. The report also predicts that Turkey's budget deficit will decrease and its public debt will remain at a reasonable level. European Commissioner for Economy Valdis Dombrovskis stated in a press conference in Brussels that the European economy is resilient despite the increasing global uncertainties. He also stated that inflation has declined faster than expected and that growth will continue at a moderate pace. He warned that the risks are still downward and that the EU needs to take decisive steps to increase its competitiveness. 'The outlook is still subject to risks, and therefore, we need to take bold steps to increase our competitiveness within the EU.' he said. 
Original language: tr
Publish date: May 19, 2025 12:36 PM
Source:[birgun.net](https://www.birgun.net/haber/ab-komisyonu-2025-buyume-tahminlerini-asagi-yonlu-revize-etti-624219)

**EU Economy Losing Steam, Commissioner Warns**
Valdis Dombrovskis, European Commissioner for Economy, stated that the European economy is losing steam and that only swift action can prevent the EU from lagging behind global growth. The European Commission has revised down its growth forecasts for the European economy, in a scenario marked by global uncertainty and trade tensions, particularly with the US. 'Global uncertainty and tensions are weighing on the growth of the European Union', said Dombrovskis, highlighting that, despite the challenges, 'the European economy remains resilient'. The Commission now expects the EU's GDP to grow by only 1.1% in 2025, a downward revision of 0.7 percentage points from the previously forecast 1.5%, and projects an acceleration to 1.5% in 2026. In the Eurozone, growth will be 0.9% this year, rising to 1.4% next year. 'This downward revision of 0.7 percentage points in accumulated terms for 2025-26 is mainly due to the impact of the tariff increase and the uncertainty caused by the abrupt changes in US commercial policy', explained Dombrovskis. The Commissioner warned that 'tensions in trade between the US and the EU, and between the US and China, can depress GDP growth and rekindle inflationary pressures'. On the other hand, 'a relaxation of trade tensions or a faster expansion of EU trade can help sustain growth'. Dombrovskis emphasized that 'the moment for the EU to act is now.' The Commissioner pointed out that 'the deterioration of global trade as a central element of the cut in EU and global GDP growth forecasts.' 'The global growth outside the EU is now projected at 3.2% for 2025 and 2026, a downward revision of 0.4 percentage points from the autumn', revealed Dombrovskis. Despite the slowdown, the European labor market remains robust. 'More jobs are being created and real wages are rising. This means more Europeans working and more money in their pockets', said the Commissioner. The unemployment rate is expected to fall to a new historical low of 5.7% in 2026, with the creation of an additional two million jobs by then. 'Tight labor markets and productivity recovery are supporting wage growth', he said, adding that 'real wages are expected to fully recover the lost purchasing power in most member states'. Inflation is decelerating more rapidly than expected in the European space, Dombrovskis noted. 'Inflation is falling faster than expected, driven by the decline in energy prices', he indicated, detailing that the rate in the euro area is expected to fall from 2.4% in 2024 to 2.1% in 2025 and 1.7% in 2026. In the EU, inflation is expected to follow a similar trajectory, falling to 1.9% in 2026. 'Several factors are exerting downward pressure on inflation, including the appreciation of the euro and increased price competition in non-energy goods', he explained. On the investment side, the recovery will be 'more timid than expected', with gross fixed capital formation growing 1.5% in 2025 and 2.4% in 2026, after a contraction of 1.9% in 2024. 'High uncertainty and tight financial conditions continue to hold back investment', warned Dombrovskis, arguing that 'more investment means a more prosperous and competitive European economy'. In the chapter on public finances, the EU's budget deficit is expected to increase slightly to 3.3% of GDP in 2025, remaining at that level in 2026, while the debt ratio rises modestly due to the increase in financing costs and the slowdown in nominal growth. However, Dombrovskis clarified that 'the impact of the application of the national escape clause of the Stability and Growth Pact, which can allow for greater expenditure in defense, is not yet reflected in the forecasts', he clarified.
Original language: pt
Publish date: May 19, 2025 11:29 AM
Source:[ECO](https://eco.sapo.pt/2025/05/19/o-momento-da-europa-para-agir-e-agora/)

**EU Economic Growth Forecast Revised Downwards to 0.9% in 2025**
The European Commission has revised its economic growth forecast for the Eurozone to 0.9% in 2025 and 1.4% in 2026, down from 1.3% and 1.6% respectively in the previous forecast. The Commission attributes this to the weakening of global trade prospects and increased uncertainty over trade policies. 'The risks for the prospects are oriented downwards', says the European Commission. The Commission also notes that an additional fragmentation of global trade could mitigate economic growth and rekindle inflationary pressures. On the positive side, a further easing of tensions between the EU and the US or a faster expansion of EU trade with other countries could support EU growth. The EU economy has started 2025 on a slightly more solid basis than expected, according to the Commission, and will continue to grow at a moderate pace this year, with an acceleration expected in 2026, despite the increase in global economic uncertainty and trade tensions. Inflation is expected to fall from 2.4% in 2024 to 2.1% in 2025 and 1.7% in 2026 in the euro area. The EU's economic growth is expected to be similar, with a decline in inflation to just under 2% in 2026. The EU economy has recorded a growth of 0.4% in the fourth quarter of 2024, above expectations, thanks to internal demand. This momentum has continued into the first quarter of 2025 (+0.3%). However, current forecasts revise downwards the growth prospects due to the worsening of global trade and political uncertainty. The global growth outside the EU is expected to be 3.2% in 2025-2026, down from 3.6% estimated in autumn. EU exports are expected to grow only 0.7% this year, driven by services. Investments, in a slight recovery after -1.8% in 2024, are expected to increase by 1.5% in 2025 and 2.4% in 2026, supported also by the Recovery Fund and the Cohesion Fund. Private consumption is expected to grow by 1.5% in 2025 and 1.6% in 2026. The labor market remains solid: 1.7 million jobs created in 2024, with an additional 2 million expected. The unemployment rate is expected to fall to a historic low of 5.7% in 2026. Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis said, 'The uncertainty on the global economic policy has reached levels never seen since the Covid-19 pandemic.' He added, 'The logic behind the US announcements on tariffs is unpredictable and apparently arbitrary, and has led to unprecedented levels of uncertainty on the global economic policy.' 'Since January, the new US administration has increased tariffs on imports from an increasing number of partner countries and on specific goods. The average tariff rate applied by the US on imports is today higher than at any other time since the 1930s.' 'The US announcements in April have also caused very high levels of market volatility. This market volatility remains high and the sentiment is fragile, as a great uncertainty on US trade and economic policy still looms,' he concluded.

**European Commission Revises Down Economic Growth Forecasts for Eurozone**

He also stated that the growth forecast for 2025 is expected to be 1.1%, and that the inflation rate is expected to decrease to 1.9% in 2026. Dombrovskis also stated that the risks to the economic forecast are downward, and that the European Union should take steps to increase its competitiveness.

**EU Revises Growth Forecast for Italy and Eurozone**
The European Commission has revised its growth forecast for the Italian economy, predicting 0.7% growth in 2025 and 0.9% in 2026, down from 1% and 1.2% respectively in the autumn forecast. **EU Revises Economic Growth Forecast Downward Due to Tariffs and Trade Uncertainty**
The European Commission has revised its forecast for the economic growth of the European Union (EU) for 2025 and 2026. The main reasons for the revision are the new import tariffs and increased uncertainty caused by the rapid changes in US trade policy. According to the report, the EU's GDP growth is expected to be 1.1% in 2025, down from the previous forecast of 1.5%. The forecast for 2026 has also been revised downward to 1.5% from 1.8%. However, the Commission expects the economic growth of the EU to accelerate to 1.5% in 2026, driven by an increase in consumption and investment. The inflation rate is expected to decrease faster than previously forecast, with consumer prices (HICP index) increasing by 2.3% in 2025 and 1.9% in 2026. The economy of the eurozone is expected to grow by 0.9% in 2025 and 1.4% in 2026, down from the previous forecasts of 1.3% and 1.6%. The unemployment rate in the EU is expected to remain at 5.9% in 2025 and decrease to 5.7% in 2026. In the eurozone, it is expected to decrease gradually from 6.4% in 2024 to 6.1% in 2026. The budget deficit of EU countries is expected to increase, with a deficit of 3.3% of GDP in 2025 and 3.4% in 2026. 'Global uncertainty and tensions are weighing on the growth of the European Union', said Dombrovskis, highlighting that, despite the challenges, 'the European economy remains resilient'. On the other hand, 'a relaxation of trade tensions or a faster expansion of EU trade can help sustain growth'. Dombrovskis emphasized that 'the moment for the EU to act is now.' The Commissioner pointed out that 'the deterioration of global trade as a central element of the cut in EU and global GDP growth forecasts.' 'The global growth outside the EU is now projected at 3.2% for 2025 and 2026, a downward revision of 0.4 percentage points from the autumn', revealed Dombrovskis. The unemployment rate is expected to fall to a new historical low of 5.7% in 2026, with the creation of an additional two million jobs by then. **OECD revises global economic growth forecast downward for 2025**
The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has revised its forecast for global economic growth in 2025 downward, citing uncertainty and tensions in the global economy. 'We are navigating turbulent waters', said Alvaro Santos Pereira, the OECD's chief economist, summarizing the global economic situation. The OECD now predicts a 3.1% growth in the global Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in 2025, down from its previous forecast of 3.3% in December. The United States, which has threatened to engage in a trade war with its main trading partners, is expected to grow by 2.2% this year and 1.6% next year, according to the OECD. The organization has lowered its forecast for US economic growth in 2025 and 2026 by 0.2 and 0.5 percentage points, respectively. The aggressive trade policies pursued by the US are particularly affecting its neighbors, Canada and Mexico, whose growth forecasts have plummeted: Canada's growth is expected to be 0.7% in 2025, down from 2.3% in December, while Mexico is expected to enter a recession this year, according to the OECD. The OECD attributes the downward revision to the ongoing trade tensions and geopolitical uncertainties affecting many countries. The OECD notes that the growth in the US, Mexico, and Canada 'will slow down as tariffs come into effect'. The organization has only taken into account the new tariffs between the US, Canada, and Mexico, as well as the tariffs on steel and aluminum, but not the threatened reciprocal tariffs mentioned by Trump or those related to the European Union. Despite this, the OECD has revised its growth forecast for 2025 downward for Germany and France, the largest and second-largest economies in the eurozone, for the second consecutive time. The OECD now expects Germany's GDP to grow by 0.4% this year, down from 0.7% in its previous forecast, while France's growth is expected to be 0.8% this year, 0.1 percentage points less than in December. 'European economies will suffer fewer direct economic effects' from the trade measures included in the OECD's projections, 'but the increase in geopolitical and political uncertainty should, nonetheless, slow down growth', explains the organization. Only Spain is expected to experience sustained growth, with a forecast of 2.6% in 2025. Japan's growth forecast for 2025 has also been revised downward to 1.1%, a 0.4 percentage point decrease. China's growth is expected to reach 4.8% in 2025, with little change from the December forecast. 'The negative consequences of the imposition of tariffs are largely offset by the adoption of reinforced support measures', notes the OECD. The OECD warns of the negative impact of trade tensions on global trade, which could not only slow down global production but also exacerbate inflation.

**ECB's Macroeconomic Projections for the Euro Area: Uncertainty and Challenges Ahead**
According to the European Central Bank's (ECB) macroeconomic projections for the euro area, the high uncertainty surrounding the geopolitical situation and economic and trade policies will negatively impact the expected economic growth. This is a consequence of the slightly weaker-than-expected economic growth at the end of 2024. The uncertainty related to both internal and external policies is high. Although the baseline projections only take into account the impact of new US-China trade tariffs, it is assumed that the negative effects of uncertainty related to possible further changes in global trade policies, especially towards the European Union, will affect exports and investments in the euro area. It is estimated that, combined with the ongoing challenges in terms of competitiveness, this will lead to a further decline in the euro area's share of export markets. Despite these unfavorable factors, the conditions remain in place for a renewed increase in the dynamics of GDP in the euro area in the projection horizon. It is expected that the growth will be driven by rising real wages and employment growth - with a strong, albeit slowing, labor market - and that consumption will remain a key driver of growth. The internal demand is expected to support the easing of financing conditions, reflected in market expectations of the future path of interest rates. The labor market is expected to remain resilient - with an average unemployment rate of 6.3% in 2025, followed by a decline to 6.2% in 2027. It is projected that productivity will grow in line with the fading of some cyclical factors that have weakened its dynamics in recent periods. However, structural problems persist. Overall, the average annual growth rate of real GDP is expected to be 0.9% in 2025, followed by an increase to 1.2% in 2026 and 1.3% in 2027. Compared to the ECB's macroeconomic projections from December 2024, the prospects for GDP growth in 2025 and 2026 have been revised down by 0.2 percentage points, but the 2027 projection remains unchanged. The weaker prospects are mainly due to a downward revision of exports and, to a lesser extent, a downward revision of investment projections. These revisions reflect the stronger-than-expected impact of uncertainty and expectations that the challenges related to competitiveness will persist longer than previously expected.

European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde stated, 'The downward revisions to the euro area's GDP growth forecasts for 2025 and 2026 reflect the decline in exports and the continued weakness in investments, partly due to the high uncertainty surrounding commercial and economic policies.' This uncertainty is affecting the export and investment sectors, leading to a decrease in growth forecasts.
